docs.title: Xpoz CLI
docs.text: Secure and instant local tunneling

docs.title: Expose your local apps to the internet securely with a single command.
Quick Install
docs.text: curl -fsSL https://cli.xpoz.xyz/install.sh | bash

docs.title: Quick Use
docs.text:
xpoz  http 3000
That's it! You'll get a public URL that forwards to http://localhost:3000

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• ⚡ One-line install & expose - Get started in seconds
  • 🔒 End-to-end security - Secure WebSocket connections (wss)
  • 🎯 Stable subdomains - Server-assigned consistent URLs
  • 📡 Full HTTP proxy - Complete header and binary support
  • 🔁 Auto reconnect - Built-in backoff and heartbeat

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Installation Guide - Detailed setup instructions
  • Quick Start - Your first tunnel in 60 seconds
  • Commands Reference - All available commands and options

docs.title: Roadmap
docs.text: Planned features and improvements for Xpoz CLI.

docs.title: 🚧 In Development
docs.text:
• Auth tokens & ACLs - Secure your tunnels with authentication
  • Config file support - Store settings in ~/.xpoz/config.yml
  • Branch/PR preview URLs - Git-integrated preview deployments

docs.title: Core Features
docs.text:
• TCP tunneling - Expose non-HTTP services
  • WebSocket native mode - Direct WebSocket proxying
  • Custom subdomains - Choose your own subdomain names

docs.title: Developer Experience
docs.text:
• VS Code extension - Manage tunnels from your editor
  • JetBrains plugin - IntelliJ, PyCharm, WebStorm integration
  • Dashboard - Web interface for tunnel management

docs.title: Enterprise
docs.text:
• Team management - Share tunnels with team members
  • Usage analytics - Monitor tunnel usage and performance
  • SLA guarantees - Enterprise-grade uptime commitments

docs.title: 📅 Timeline
docs.text: Quarter Focus Q3 2025 Auth tokens, Config files Q4 2025 TCP tunneling, Dashboard Q1 2026 IDE integrations, Team features

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Want to help build these features? Check out our contribution guide.

docs.title: Self-Hosting
docs.text: You can run your own Xpoz tunnel server for complete control and privacy.

docs.title: Server Requirements
docs.text:
• Linux server with public IP
  • Domain name (for SSL certificates)
  • Docker (recommended) or Go runtime

docs.title: Docker Setup (Recommended)
docs.text:
# Clone the server repository
git clone https://github.com/your-username/xpoz-server
cd xpoz-server

# Configure environment
cp .env.example .env
# Edit .env with your domain and settings

# Start the server
docker-compose up -d

docs.title: Manual Setup
docs.text:
# Download server binary
wget https://github.com/your-username/xpoz-server/releases/latest/download/xpoz-server-linux-amd64

# Make executable
chmod +x xpoz-server-linux-amd64

# Run server
./xpoz-server-linux-amd64 --domain your-domain.com --port 443

docs.title: Client Configuration
docs.text:
Point your CLI to your server:

xpoz expose http 3000 --server wss://your-domain.com

Or set as default:

export XPOZ_SERVER=wss://your-domain.com

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common issues and solutions.

docs.title: "Failed to connect to tunnel server"
docs.text:
Causes: - Network connectivity issues - Firewall blocking WebSocket connections - Server is down

Solutions: 

# Test connectivity
curl -I https://api.xpoz.xyz

# Try alternative server
xpoz  http 3000 --server wss://backup.xpoz.xyz

# Check firewall settings

docs.title: "Tunnel disconnected"
docs.text:
Causes: - Network interruption - Server restart - Idle timeout

Solutions: - The CLI automatically reconnects with backoff - Check your internet connection - Ensure your local app is still running

docs.title: "Slow response times"
docs.text:
Solutions: 

# Reduce max connections
xpoz  http 3000 --max-connections 10

# Use a server closer to your location
xpoz  http 3000 --server wss://eu.xpoz.xyz

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you're still having issues:

  1. Check the GitHub Issues
  2. Enable debug logging: XPOZ_DEBUG=1 xpoz http 3000
  3. Create a new issue with your debug output ```

docs.title: docs/about/roadmap.md
docs.text: ```markdown

docs.title: Automatic Install (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to install Xpoz CLI:

curl -fsSL https://get.xpoz.xyz/install.sh | bash

docs.title: This script will:
docs.text:
• Download the latest binary for your platform
  • Install it to /usr/local/bin/xpoz
  • Make it executable and available in your PATH

docs.title: Download Binary
docs.text:
Visit the (https://github.com/ildysilva/xpoz_cli/releases)[releases page] and download the appropriate binary for your platform:

  • xpoz-linux-amd64 - Linux 64-bit
  • xpoz-darwin-amd64 - macOS Intel
  • xpoz-darwin-arm64 - macOS Apple Silicon

docs.title: Install Binary
docs.text:
Make it executable 

# Make it executable
chmod +x xpoz-*


# Move to PATH
sudo mv xpoz-* /usr/local/bin/xpoz

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
xpoz --version

You should see the version number displayed.

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Linux or macOS
  • Internet connection for tunneling
  • No additional dependencies required

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get your first tunnel running in under 60 seconds.

docs.title: 1. Start Your Local App
docs.text:
First, make sure you have a local application running. For example:

# Simple HTTP server on port 3000
python -m http.server 3000

docs.title: 2. Expose It
docs.text:
In another terminal, expose your local app:

xpoz expose http 3000

You'll see output like:

✓ Connected to tunnel server
✓ Tunnel established
→ Local:  http://localhost:3000
→ Public: https://abc123.xpoz.xyz

Press Ctrl+C to stop the tunnel

docs.title: 3. Test It
docs.text:
Open the public URL in your browser or test with curl:

curl https://abc123.xpoz.xyz

That's it! Your local app is now accessible from anywhere on the internet.

docs.title: Web Development
docs.text:
# Expose your dev server
xpoz expose http 3000

docs.title: API Testing
docs.text:
# Share your API with teammates
xpoz expose http 8080

docs.title: Webhook Testing
docs.text:
# Receive webhooks locally
xpoz expose http 4000

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Learn about configuration options
  • Explore all available commands

docs.title: http
docs.text:
Expose a local HTTP server to the internet.

xpoz  http <port> [options]

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Basic usage
xpoz  http 3000


# Custom server
xpoz  http 3000 --server wss://ws.xpoz.xyz

# Limit connections
xpoz  http 3000 --max-connections 50

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description Default --server Custom tunnel server URL wss://api.xpoz.xyz --max-connections Maximum concurrent connections 100

docs.title: Global Options
docs.text: Option Description --help, -h Show help --version, -v Show version

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text:
Code Meaning 0 Success 1 General error 2 Connection failed 3 Invalid arguments 
### docs/usage/configuration.md
```markdown
# Configuration

Xpoz CLI can be configured through command-line flags or environment variables.

## Environment Variables

| Variable | Description | Default |
|----------|-------------|---------|
| `XPOZ_SERVER` | Default tunnel server | `wss://api.xpoz.xyz` |
| `XPOZ_MAX_CONNECTIONS` | Default max connections | `100` |

## Examples

```bash
# Set default server
export XPOZ_SERVER=wss://my-server.com
xpoz expose http 3000

# Set max connections
export XPOZ_MAX_CONNECTIONS=25
xpoz  http 3000

docs.title: Configuration File (Planned)
docs.text:
Future versions will support a config file at ~/.xpoz/config.yml:

server: wss://my-server.com
max_connections: 50
auth_token: your-token-here
